text: The tallest tree ever measured reliably is Hyperion, a Coast redwood (Sequoia sempervirens) in California's Redwood National Park, standing at 116.07 meters (380.8 feet).
The oldest verified living tree is Methuselah, a Great Basin bristlecone pine (Pinus longaeva) in California, aged 4,857 years.
The General Sherman Tree, a giant sequoia, is the largest tree by volume at 1,487 cubic meters (52,500 cubic feet) of wood.
A wild fig tree growing in Echo Caves near Ohrigstad, South Africa, has roots going 120 meters (400 feet) deep, the deepest roots known of any tree.
The Árbol del Tule, a Montezuma cypress in Mexico, has the stoutest trunk in the world with a diameter of 11.62 meters (38.1 feet).
The Thimmamma Marrimanu banyan tree in India has the broadest crown of any tree, spreading 180 meters (591 feet) in diameter with hundreds of trunks.
Historical records suggest a Mountain ash (Eucalyptus regnans) tree measured in Australia in 1865 reached 147.2 meters (483 feet), but this cannot be verified today.
Plants can sense and respond to at least 15 different environmental stimuli including light, gravity, touch, temperature, chemicals, moisture, infections, and sound.
The Mimosa pudica (sensitive plant) rapidly folds its leaves in response to touch, generating electrical signals similar to action potentials in animal neurons.
Plants have internal circadian clocks synchronized with solar time, allowing them to track day length and determine the season, which controls flowering time (photoperiodism).
The vine Boquila trifoliata can mimic the shape of leaves of plants it climbs on, even mimicking artificial plastic leaves, suggesting plants may have a form of vision.
Plants produce neurotransmitter-like molecules including glutamate, GABA, acetylcholine, melatonin, and serotonin, usually associated with animal nervous systems.
Plants can transmit electrical signals throughout their bodies using action potentials, affecting processes like photosynthesis, flowering, and wound responses.
Wounded plants release volatile odors like methyl jasmonate and methyl salicylate that neighboring plants detect and respond to by increasing their chemical defenses.
Plants can detect vibrations caused by caterpillars chewing and respond by increasing production of defensive chemicals like glucosinolates.
Sunflowers exhibit heliotropism, following the sun across the sky during the day by differential growth on opposite sides of the stem.
Plant roots can sense gravity using starch-filled amyloplasts that fall in the direction of gravitational pull, allowing roots to grow downward.
Carnivory has evolved independently at least 12 times in plants across five different orders of flowering plants, representing remarkable convergent evolution.
There are over 800 species of carnivorous plants, with about 3 new species discovered per year since 2000, and roughly one quarter are threatened with extinction.
The Venus flytrap can close its trap in less than a second, using a mechanism where cells rapidly change shape from convex to concave when triggered.
The Venus flytrap has a simple memory: its trap requires two separate touches between 0.5 to 30 seconds apart to close, preventing false triggers from rain or debris.
Bladderworts (Utricularia) create a partial vacuum inside bladder traps, then suck in prey in milliseconds when trigger hairs are touched—the fastest known plant movement.
Nepenthes rajah pitcher plants can grow pitchers large enough to occasionally trap small mammals and reptiles, not just insects.
Nepenthes lowii pitcher plants supplement their diet with tree shrew droppings—the shrews use the pitcher as a toilet while feeding on nectar.
Sarracenia flava pitcher plants lace their nectar with coniine, a toxic alkaloid also found in hemlock, to intoxicate prey and increase trapping efficiency.
The sundew Drosera burmanii can bend its tentacles 180 degrees in about one minute to trap prey, using rapid acid growth rather than turgor changes.
Some pygmy sundews are so dependent on insect nitrogen that they lack nitrate reductase enzymes, making them unable to use nitrogen from soil.
Charles Darwin spent 16 years studying carnivorous plants and published 'Insectivorous Plants' in 1875, recognizing it as convergent evolution.
Darlingtonia californica (cobra plant) confuses trapped insects with false exits—transparent windows in its hood that appear as escape routes but aren't.
Genlisea (corkscrew plants) trap microscopic soil organisms using Y-shaped underground leaves with inward-pointing hairs that force prey toward digestive chambers.
Mycorrhizal networks were discovered in 1997 by Suzanne Simard, revealing that trees share resources through underground fungal connections called the 'Wood Wide Web'.
Plants can provide up to 30% of the carbon they fix through photosynthesis to their mycorrhizal fungal partners in exchange for nitrogen and phosphorus.
Douglas fir trees injured by insects can send chemical warning signals through mycorrhizal networks to neighboring ponderosa pines, which then produce defense enzymes.
Carbon flow direction in mycorrhizal networks shifts seasonally—toward young maple saplings in spring, then toward trout lilies developing roots in fall.
More carbon is exchanged between closely related Douglas firs sharing a network than between distantly related trees, suggesting kin recognition in plants.
Black walnut trees release juglone, an allelopathic chemical transferred through mycorrhizal networks that inhibits growth and water uptake in neighboring plants.
Mycorrhizal symbiosis evolved before plants colonized land, with evolutionary origins dating back over 450 million years.
Tomato plants connected via mycorrhizal networks can 'prime' uninfected neighbors' defenses when one plant is attacked by fungal pathogens.
The Society for the Protection of Underground Networks (SPUN) released the first high-resolution map of Earth's mycorrhizal networks in 2025, revealing 90% remain unprotected.
Monotropa (Indian pipe) plants cannot photosynthesize and obtain all their nutrients by parasitizing mycorrhizal fungal networks connected to other trees.
Foxgloves produce digoxin and digitoxin, cardiac glycosides used for centuries in heart medicine, which deter herbivores by affecting heart rhythm.
Over 3,000 alkaloids have been identified in plants, including nicotine, caffeine, morphine, cocaine, and quinine, all evolved as herbivore deterrents.
Cyanogenic glycosides in plants release hydrogen cyanide when cell membranes are broken by herbivores, blocking cellular respiration in the attacker.
Grasses use indigestible silica phytoliths to defend against herbivores, causing rapid wear to mammal teeth and insect mandibles.
Caterpillar-damaged plants release volatile organic compounds that attract parasitic wasps to prey on the caterpillars—a form of indirect defense.
When herbivores eat trees, saliva left on leaves triggers increased salicylic acid production, signaling the tree to produce more defensive tannins.
African Acacia trees have long spines low in their canopy but very short spines high up, where they're safe from giraffe browsing.
Vachellia collinsii acacia trees provide hollow thorns as housing for protective ants and produce food bodies as payment—a classic mutualistic defense.
Tall fescue grass harbors endophytic fungi (Neotyphodium) that produce alkaloids toxic to herbivores, protecting both grass and fungus.
Passiflora passion vines have structures resembling butterfly eggs on their leaves, discouraging butterflies from laying real eggs there.
Lithops 'pebble plants' evolved camouflage to look like small stones in their South African environment, hiding from herbivores in plain sight.
New Zealand shrubs evolved wide-branching structures believed to be defenses against browsing by the now-extinct moa birds.
Raphides are needle-sharp calcium oxalate crystals in plant tissues that make ingestion painful and deliver toxins more efficiently.
The earliest evidence of herbivory dates to around 420 million years ago, within 20 million years of the first fossilized plant sporangia.
Horseradish releases allyl isothiocyanate—its pungent ingredient—only when crushed, keeping the toxic compound safely stored until an herbivore attacks.
Kudzu vine, introduced to the US to control erosion, can grow up to 30 cm (1 foot) per day and is now one of the world's worst invasive species.
Invasive species management costs approximately $1.4 trillion annually worldwide, with economic damage alone exceeding $423 billion per year.
Cheatgrass has altered fire regimes in western North America so severely that it provides fuel for frequent fires that native plants cannot survive.
Japanese knotweed (Reynoutria japonica) is considered one of the world's worst invasive species, able to grow through concrete and decrease property values.
Water hyacinth can double its population in just two weeks, forms dense mats blocking light and oxygen, and creates massive management costs worldwide.
Lantana camara, originally from Central and South America, is now invasive in over 60 countries and is highly toxic to livestock.
Mother of thousands (Kalanchoe daigremontana) produces allelopathic compounds that chemically inhibit competing plants from growing nearby.
Spotted knapweed can alter which plants an AM fungus connects to, restructuring underground networks to increase its competitive advantage.
In Cape Town, removing invasive plants like acacias, pines, and eucalyptus would generate 50 billion liters of additional water annually within 5 years.
Barbed goatgrass thrives on serpentine soils toxic to most plants, with low nutrients and heavy metal toxicity, allowing it to dominate and crowd out natives.
In India, invasive plants have invaded 66% of natural areas, reducing native forage plants and threatening the long-term survival of tigers and other carnivores.
Dandelions reproduce asexually through apomixis, producing seeds without fertilization that are genetically identical clones of the parent plant.
Quaking aspen can form clonal colonies from root systems; one colony called 'Pando' in Utah is over 80,000 years old and covers 106 acres.
Orchids have the most specialized pollination systems, with some mimicking female insect pheromones to attract males who 'mate' with the flower.
Orchidaceae (orchid family) is the largest flowering plant family with up to 35,000 species, many using deceptive pollination strategies.
Cycads and ginkgos are the only surviving seed plants with motile sperm that swim using flagella, a primitive trait dating back 350 million years.
Sexual reproduction in the green alga Volvox carteri is triggered by oxidative stress, suggesting sex evolved as an adaptive response to DNA damage.
The cactus Mammillaria hernandezii stores some seeds inside its stem and releases more when it senses adequate water, a primitive form of parental care.
Angiosperms (flowering plants) use double fertilization, unique in biology, where one sperm fertilizes the egg and another creates nutrient-rich endosperm.
Liverworts reproduce using gemmae, single cells or cell masses that detach and grow into genetically identical new plants.
The earliest Sumerian clay tablets from around 3000 BC list hundreds of medicinal plants including opium and myrrh.
The Ebers Papyrus from ancient Egypt, circa 1550 BC, describes over 850 plant medicines including aloe, cannabis, castor bean, garlic, and juniper.
Dioscorides' De materia medica from 60 AD documented over 1,000 medicine recipes using 600+ plants and remained authoritative for 1,500 years.
Willow bark has been used for millennia to relieve pain; its active compound, salicylic acid, is the metabolite of aspirin.
Morphine was the first alkaloid isolated from a plant (opium poppy) in 1806, launching modern pharmaceutical chemistry.
The anticancer drug taxol (paclitaxel) was discovered in Pacific yew bark in 1971, and vincristine from Madagascar periwinkle treats leukemia.
Over 50,000 medicinal plants are used across the world, with about 17,810 species confirmed to have medicinal uses by Kew Gardens.
About one quarter of drugs prescribed in modern medicine are derived from medicinal plants, including quinine, digoxin, and morphine.
Daffodils contain galantamine, an alkaloid now licensed for treating Alzheimer's disease, evolved as a bitter-tasting herbivore deterrent.
The global market for medicinal and aromatic plants was US$68 billion per year in 2023, growing 10-20% annually.
Of 185 cancer-treating small-molecule drugs approved from 1981-2019, 65% were derived from or inspired by natural plant substances.
Ötzi the Iceman, frozen in the Alps for 5,000+ years, carried a mushroom possibly used as medicine against whipworm parasites.
A 2020 Kew Gardens report identified 723 medicinal plants at risk of extinction, partly due to over-collection for medicine.
Charles Darwin proposed the 'root-brain hypothesis' in 1880, suggesting root tips act like simple brains directing plant movement.
Jagadish Chandra Bose invented instruments to measure electrical responses in plants in the early 1900s, considered the 'father of plant neurobiology'.
Researchers in 2017 found a 'decision-making center' in root tips of dormant Arabidopsis seeds that determines when germination occurs.
When exposed to anesthetics, Venus flytraps stop generating electrical signals and their traps remain open—similar to anesthetized animals.
French bean plants can detect and grow toward a support cane 30 cm away, adjusting growth patterns to use it as future support.
Plants can detect soil volume and adapt growth accordingly, independent of nutrient availability, showing spatial awareness.
The term 'plant neurobiology' was so controversial that the Society for Plant Neurobiology renamed itself Society of Plant Signaling and Behavior in 2009.
36 plant scientists published a 2007 paper titled 'Plant Neurobiology: No Brain, No Gain?' arguing plants lack neurons and true cognition.
Plants can exhibit associative learning behaviors similar to Pavlovian conditioning, though this remains controversial among scientists.
Cleve Backster's 1966 experiments claiming plants respond to human emotions were later debunked when controlled studies found no repeatable effect.
Rafflesia arnoldii produces the world's largest individual flower, up to 1.5 meters (5 feet) in diameter and weighing 10-12 kg.
Rafflesia has no roots, stems, leaves, or chlorophyll—it's a parasite that only becomes visible when its corpse-scented flowers emerge from host vines.
The pelican flower (Aristolochia grandiflora) produces the world's longest flower with a sepal extending up to 3-4 meters long while only 1 cm wide.
Balanophora involucrata has the world's smallest flowers at just 25 micrometers wide, with a single flower head containing up to 10 million tiny florets.
The world's smallest complete flower is Parish's wild buckwheat at only 0.6 mm long, yet containing sepals, petals, stamens, and carpels.
The talipot palm (Corypha umbraculifera) produces the largest branched inflorescence of any plant, flowers only once in its 60-year lifetime, then dies.
The titan arum (corpse flower) has the largest unbranched inflorescence in the world and smells like rotting flesh to attract pollinating carrion flies.
The world record for heaviest fruit is a pumpkin weighing 1,247 kg (2,749 lbs), grown in California in 2023.
Wolffia produces the world's smallest fruit at just 0.30 mm long weighing about 70 micrograms, yet this tiny fruit takes up a third of the parent plant's length.
Ricin from castor beans is one of the most potent plant toxins known, with just 1-2 milligrams potentially lethal to an adult human.
The manchineel tree is so toxic that standing under it during rain can cause skin blisters, and burning its wood produces eye-damaging smoke.
A stand of genetically identical Huon pine trees in Tasmania is over 10,500 years old, reproducing vegetatively though no single tree is that age.
European Yews may live over 5,000 years, but accurate aging is difficult because ancient specimens become hollow, losing their heartwood.
Baobab trees store large amounts of water in their soft wood trunks, causing their girth to vary by about 2.5% between wet and dry seasons.
The Sunland Baobab in South Africa became famous for having a bar and wine cellar operating inside its massive hollow trunk before it split in 2017.
Sacred fig trees grow adventitious roots from branches that become new trunks when reaching the ground—one tree can have hundreds of such trunks.
Giant sequoias have the thickest limbs of any tree species, with some branches reaching 3.8 meters (12.6 feet) in diameter.
El Drago Milenario, a Dracaena draco on Tenerife, reportedly has superficial roots extending 200 meters (660 feet) long.
The Hundred Horse Chestnut tree in Sicily was measured at 57.9 meters circumference in 1780—actually multiple fused trunks appearing as one.
The phylloxera pest nearly destroyed French vineyards in the 1800s until resistant American Vitis labrusca rootstocks were used for grafting.
Some plants can photosynthesize even while their leaves are still red in autumn, using pigments other than chlorophyll.
Drosophyllum lusitanicum, the Portuguese dewy pine, is unusual among carnivorous plants for growing in near-desert conditions with minimal water.
Nepenthes ampullaria has evolved away from carnivory, catching falling leaves in its pitchers instead of insects for nutrients.
Utricularia macrorhiza bladderworts can adjust the number of bladders they produce based on the expected density of prey in their environment.
Sarracenia pitcher plants produce phyllodes (flat, non-carnivorous leaves) in winter when light levels are too low for carnivory to be worthwhile.
Roridula plants look like sundews but don't digest prey directly—they rely on symbiotic assassin bugs to eat trapped insects and leave nutrient-rich droppings.
The liverworts Colura and Pleurozia have sac-shaped leaves that trap and may digest microscopic ciliates—possible carnivory in non-flowering plants.
Carnivorous plants evolved where soil nutrients are extremely limiting but light and water are abundant—carnivory compensates for poor soil.
Drosera glanduligera combines flypaper and snap trap mechanisms—a 'catapult-flypaper' trap unique in the plant kingdom.
Philcoxia plants have underground leaves that trap and digest nematode worms—a unique adaptation in the Plantaginaceae family.
The Venus flytrap exists naturally only in a 120-kilometer radius around Wilmington, North Carolina—one of the most restricted ranges of any plant.
Heliamphora pitcher plants live on South American tepuis (table mountains) like Mount Roraima, having evolved overflow mechanisms for high rainfall.
Carnivorous bromeliads (Brocchinia reducta) trap insects in waxy urns filled with water, one of only two carnivorous plant evolutions in this family.
Nepenthes bicalcarata has two sharp thorns projecting over its pitcher opening that may help lure insects to precarious positions.
Butterworts (Pinguicula) have mucilage glands so short their leaves appear shiny but not obviously carnivorous, yet are extremely effective insect traps.
The oldest carnivorous plant evolution dates to 85.6 million years ago, while Brocchinia reducta evolved carnivory only 1.9 million years ago.
Plants infected with aphids only express salicylic acid pathways when connected to uninfested plants via mycorrhizal networks, showing coordinated defense.
A paper birch tree transferring carbon to a Douglas fir showed a threefold increase in its own photosynthesis rate—the sender benefits too.
Seedlings planted near existing trees with mycorrhizal networks have higher survival rates and access to greater fungal diversity.
Allelochemicals (plant-produced competitive toxins) travel through mycorrhizal networks at 2-4 times higher concentrations than through soil alone.
Trees send warning signals including chemical, hormonal, and slow-pulsing electrical signals similar to animal nervous systems.
Plants release volatile organic compounds primarily during times of day when third trophic level organisms (predators of herbivores) are active.
Fresh grass growth can be high in prussic acid (hydrogen cyanide) content, potentially poisoning grazing livestock during rapid growth periods.
Human cooking may have evolved partly to overcome plant chemical defenses—many enzyme inhibitors in grains and legumes are denatured by heat.
Nicotine extracted from tobacco was used as an insecticide as early as 1690, making it one of the first botanical pesticides in history.
Pyrethrin from Chrysanthemum flowers is still used as a natural insecticide today, having been employed for centuries.
Some plants experience 'overcompensation' when attacked by herbivores—they actually grow better and have higher fitness after damage.
The toad plant (Stapelia gigantea) helps seedlings of other plants survive in arid environments by providing shade and protecting them from herbivores.
Zebra mussels increase lake floor habitat complexity, providing crevices for invertebrates—some invasive species accidentally benefit ecosystems.
The cost of invasive species has quadrupled every decade since 1970, driven by increased globalization and international trade.
Ship ballast water transports approximately 10,000 species per day between ports around the world, many becoming invasive.
Invasive alien species have caused the extinction of approximately 90 amphibian species through the spread of chytrid fungus via international trade.
Eurasian watermilfoil fills lakes so densely with plants that it complicates fishing, boating, and other recreational activities.
Garlic mustard is one of the most problematic invasive plants in eastern North American forests, threatening to change forest tree composition.
Introduced cordgrass can hybridize with native California cordgrass, threatening its existence in San Francisco Bay through genetic pollution.
Opium poppy was listed on Sumerian clay tablets around 3000 BC—among humanity's oldest documented medicinal plants.
Ephedra plant contains ephedrine, used in Chinese medicine for millennia and now a common decongestant and stimulant compound.
Cinchona bark contains quinine, which saved countless lives from malaria and was the first effective treatment for the disease.
Chaulmoogra oil from Hydnocarpus trees was used to treat leprosy in Chinese medicine for centuries before modern antibiotics.
Tobacco was considered a panacea in Europe after the Columbian Exchange and has 'probably been responsible for more deaths than any other herb.'
Thymol from thyme has antiseptic properties and was once used as a vermifuge (anti-worm medicine) before modern drugs.
Plants used in traditional medicine for the same conditions belong to the same plant groups across Nepal, New Zealand, and South Africa—suggesting real efficacy.
Many phytochemicals including curcumin and resveratrol are 'pan-assay interference compounds' that produce unreliable results in drug discovery studies.
Only two botanical drug candidates were approved by the FDA between 1999-2012 despite hundreds of applications.
Datura stramonium (thornapple) contains atropine and was used for asthma, but it's also a powerful and potentially fatal hallucinogen.
George Bernard Shaw was 'intensely disturbed' witnessing a demonstration where a cabbage appeared to have 'convulsions' while being boiled.
The book 'The Secret Life of Plants' (1973) severely damaged the credibility of plant intelligence research by mixing legitimate science with pseudoscience.
Dorothy Retallack's 1973 experiments claiming plants died from acid rock but thrived with classical music were poorly controlled and not scientifically valid.
MythBusters tested plant perception in 2006 and found results were not repeatable when proper controls were applied.
The book 'The Hidden Life of Trees' by Peter Wohlleben was criticized by scientists for anthropomorphizing trees with friendships, fear, love, and pain.
Gustav Fechner in 1848 first suggested plants can feel emotions and that one could promote healthy growth with talk, attention, and affection.
Plants under water stress release abscisic acid that causes developmental changes—similar to how signal transductions in neural networks cause muscle responses.
Plant memory may be disadvantageous—'forgetting' brief stress periods may be more beneficial than remembering them, allowing faster return to normal growth.
Scientists found that the heritability of mycorrhizal colonization in cowpeas provides evidence that plant-fungus interactions have evolved genetically.
The idea of plant 'neuronal' structures was controversial, but plants do have cell information-processing systems analogous to some animal functions.
Plants can respond to stress by releasing carbon from their roots to connected plants through mycorrhizal networks—environmental stress sharing.
Douglas fir seedlings grow better when planted near the root systems of mature Douglas firs than when isolated from established trees.
Some Sumatran pitcher plants like Nepenthes inermis use sticky pitcher fluid, combining pitfall and flypaper trapping mechanisms.
Triphyophyllum peltatum is only carnivorous in its juvenile phase—it becomes a non-carnivorous liana as an adult, possibly needing nutrients for flowering.
Carnivorous plants are poor competitors in nutrient-rich environments—they invest too heavily in trap structures that have no advantage when nutrients are abundant.
Over 300 'protocarnivorous' plant species show some but not all carnivorous traits—they may represent evolutionary transitional forms.
The Venus flytrap's snap trap mechanism involves cells rapidly changing water content through ion pumping, allowing the trap to flip from convex to concave.
Pitcher plant digestive fluids contain enzymes like proteases, chitinases (to break insect exoskeletons), phosphatases, and nucleases.
Carnivorous plants on all continents except Antarctica show convergent evolution—similar solutions to nutrient limitation evolved independently multiple times.
Trigger hairs in Venus flytraps generate action potentials that propagate to cells in the midrib, causing the dramatic trap closure.
Venus flytrap leaves can be reused only 3-4 times for digestion before becoming unresponsive to stimulation.
The snap trap of Venus flytraps and waterwheel plants evolved from ancestral flypaper traps, with stalked glands becoming trigger hairs and teeth.
Calcuim molecules move dynamically within Venus flytrap cells when touching prey, likely producing defense hormones that trigger leaf movement.
The waterwheel plant (Aldrovanda vesiculosa) is an aquatic snap trap specialist that catches small invertebrates using the same mechanism as Venus flytraps.
Tuberous sundews form tubers to survive dry Australian summers—a form of aestivation uncommon among carnivorous plants.
Cephalotus follicularis (Albany pitcher plant) from Western Australia has moccasin-like pitchers with pronounced rims that prevent trapped prey from climbing out.
Heliamphora tatei is the only species in its genus that produces digestive enzymes—most Heliamphora rely solely on bacterial digestion.
Some pitcher plants have phytotelmata—the water pools inside pitchers become entire micro-ecosystems hosting frogs, insects, and other organisms.
Flowering plants (angiosperms) dominate modern plant life with over 300,000 species—more than all other plant groups combined.
Asteraceae (sunflower family) is the second-largest flowering plant family with about 22,000 species of composite flowers.
Seed plants evolved about 350 million years ago in the Paleozoic era, with pollen grains protecting male gametes during transfer.
Mosses and liverworts have motile sperm that must swim through water films to reach eggs—an ancestral aquatic adaptation.
Fern gametophytes (prothalli) are independent, heart-shaped, green plants completely unlike the adult fern sporophytes.
Plants can breed cultivars with individual desirable characteristics through vegetative propagation, bypassing the randomness of sexual reproduction.
Grafting allows four or more related fruit varieties to grow on a single tree by joining stems onto established rootstocks.
Mistletoe plants are parasitic and spread by birds that eat their sticky berries—the seeds pass through and germinate on new host branches.
The Wollemi pine was thought extinct for 200 million years until fewer than 100 trees were discovered in Australia in 1994.
Giant sequoias can survive forest fires due to bark up to 3 feet thick that protects the living tissue beneath.
Coast redwoods can reproduce by sprouting from burls and root systems, allowing individuals to persist even if the main trunk is destroyed.
Bald cypresses can live over 2,650 years—among the oldest non-clonal organisms in eastern North America.
Saharan cypresses (Cupressus dupreziana) have lived over 2,200 years in the extreme desert environment of southern Algeria.
The Sacred Fig at Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka is one of the oldest human-planted trees at 2,302 years, grown from a cutting of the Bodhi tree.
Trees may reverse transpiration streams and absorb water through needles in foggy environments, exceeding theoretical maximum heights.
Tasmania has been called a 'global gigantism hotspot'—many of the world's tallest hardwood trees grow there.
A South Tibetan cypress was discovered in 2023 at 102.3 meters—the tallest tree in Asia and second-tallest species after coast redwoods.
Mountain ash trees (Eucalyptus regnans) in Australia may have historically exceeded 140 meters, but logging eliminated the tallest specimens.
The Kauri tree Tāne Mahuta in New Zealand has the largest total wood volume outside California at 516 cubic meters including branches.
The Centurion eucalyptus tree in Tasmania reached 100.5 meters in 2018 but lost 4 meters of height due to fire damage.
Menara in Malaysia is the tallest tropical tree at 97.58 meters—a yellow meranti (Shorea faguetiana).
White Knight, a manna gum eucalyptus in Tasmania, died likely due to more frequent heatwaves and reduced rainfall from climate change.
African baobabs in Zimbabwe have been carbon-dated to 2,419 years old—among the oldest flowering trees on Earth.
The oldest verified olive tree is 1,163 years old (±131 years) in the Sisters Olive Trees of Noah, Lebanon—previously claimed to be 6,000 years.
Dinizia excelsa trees in the Amazon reach 88.5 meters—the tallest trees in South America.
The Monkira Monster coolibah tree in Australia has a crown spread over 200 meters (656 feet) in circumference despite growing in arid conditions.
The Pechanga Great Oak in California has a crown spread of 53.6 meters (176 feet) and is estimated at over 1,000 years old.
Yew tree measurements historically varied wildly—the Tisbury Yew's girth was recorded as anywhere from 9.0 to 11.28 meters over 125 years.
Over 50 tree species are known to exceed 4.45 meters diameter (14 meters circumference)—true giants of the plant kingdom.
Plants have photoreceptor proteins (phototropins, cryptochromes, and phytochromes) that react very specifically to certain wavelengths of light.
Some plants grow toward darkness (skototropism) rather than light—the vine Monstera gigantea uses this to find tree trunks to climb.
Plants produce more protective UV-absorbing pigments when exposed to high ultraviolet radiation—sunscreen at the cellular level.
Poplar stems can detect both reorientation and inclination, having a sense of equilibrioception similar to animal balance organs.
Climbing plants like tomatoes exhibit thigmotropism—they curl around objects in response to touch, allowing them to climb.
Plants use ATP, nitric oxide, and reactive oxygen species for signaling in ways similar to how animals use these molecules.
Plant root tips can use sound to locate water—they grow toward the sound of flowing water before actually reaching it.
Jasmonate levels increase rapidly in plants during mechanical stimulation like tendril coiling—a rapid chemical response to touch.
Plants have 'phototropism' toward light and 'gravitropism' responding to gravity—oppositely in shoots (up) versus roots (down).
Seeds of many plants require light exposure to germinate, detected through phytochrome signaling—ensuring they're near the soil surface.
Without gravity, plants cannot orient themselves properly—space station experiments show roots and shoots grow randomly.
The hormone auxin is redistributed through 'polar auxin transport' in response to light and gravity, causing differential growth.
Green leaf volatiles are chemicals released when plants are wounded that can be detected and responded to by neighboring plants.
Electrochemical gradients are vital to plant cell health—if a cell ever reaches equilibrium with its environment, it is dead.
Actin-based cytoplasmic streaming in plants can be influenced by action potentials—electrical signals affect internal cellular movement.
Plant behavior includes active foraging for light and nutrients by changing architecture, branch growth, and direction.
Charles Elton's 1958 book 'The Ecology of Invasion by Animals and Plants' created the foundation for modern invasion biology.
Invasive plants can undergo 'lag effect'—remaining at low population levels for years before suddenly exploding in numbers.
Island ecosystems are more prone to invasion because native species evolved with few competitors and predators.
In New Zealand, the first invasive species were dogs and rats brought by Polynesian settlers around 1300 CE, devastating endemic wildlife.
Forage loss from invasive weeds on US pastures amounts to nearly $1 billion annually—a major agricultural economic impact.
Invasive plants can provide habitat for endangered species—the southwestern willow flycatcher mainly nests in non-native tamarisk.
Intensive fenced area management (clearing, mowing) actually makes areas more prone to invasive species by reducing native plant competition.
Climate change increases ocean temperatures and shifts species ranges, allowing invasive organisms in ship ballast to survive in new locations.
Invasive species cause 400 of 958 endangered species under the US Endangered Species Act to be at risk—the leading human-caused threat.
Invasive chestnut blight and Dutch elm disease are plant pathogens that have devastated North American forests.
The overall economic cost of invasive species in Europe from 1960-2020 was around $140 billion—likely a conservative estimate.
Damage costs from invasive species in France are nearly 8 times higher than management expenditure—reactive rather than preventive spending.
Yellow starthistle (Centaurea solstitialis) is unpalatable to livestock due to thorns and spines, and is toxic to horses.
Giant hogweed causes severe photodermatitis—its sap makes skin extremely sensitive to sunlight, causing burns and permanent scarring.
Invasive species can rapidly evolve in new environments, with bottleneck and founder effects potentially leading to increased genetic variance and adaptation.
The 'enemy release hypothesis' explains invasive success: species in new habitats lack natural predators, competitors, and diseases that controlled them at home.
Acclimation societies in colonial times deliberately introduced European plants and animals, feeling this 'improved' nature.
Parthenium hysterophorus is a highly allergenic invasive weed that reduces crop yields and threatens wildlife in tiger reserves.
Tamarisk (salt cedar) is invasive in the American Southwest, consuming large amounts of groundwater and altering riparian ecosystems.
Smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora) invasion alters nutrient cycling in coastal wetlands, changing ecosystem functions.
Ambrosia artemisiifolia (common ragweed) is one of the most costly invasive species in France due to severe allergenic impacts.
86% of invasive species could potentially be identified from ecological traits alone before they become established.
Plants can change their attractiveness to herbivores by altering their size or quality, reducing the rate at which they're consumed.
Many plants removed iodine from their metabolism when adapting to land—iodine is essential for animals but not for plant cells.
Some glycoside plant toxins work by blocking iodide transporters—the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) that is vital to animals.
The diversification of flowering plants in the Cretaceous is associated with a sudden burst of insect speciation—co-evolution in action.
There was a gap of 50-100 million years between each new plant organ evolving (roots, seeds, etc.) and herbivores evolving to eat it.
Some herbivore caterpillars create 'moats' by cutting partial circles in leaves to block plant defensive chemicals before feeding.
Systemic acquired resistance (SAR) and plant-induced systemic resistance are modes of defense where initial damage triggers whole-plant protection.
Tannins give unripe persimmons their extremely astringent and bitter flavor—the same chemicals that make the fruit a herbivore deterrent.
Rhododendron leaves are poisonous due to diterpenes, a class of terpenoid compounds evolved as herbivore defenses.
Saponins in plants can lyse (burst) red blood cells of herbivores—a powerful defensive mechanism.
Condensed tannins are polymers of up to 50 flavonoid molecules that inhibit digestion by binding to plant proteins.
Water hemlock contains cicutoxin, a highly toxic polyyne derived from fatty acid metabolism that causes violent seizures.
Lathyrus sativus (grass pea) produces neurotoxic amino acids that cause paralysis when eaten as a staple food during famines.
Fluoroacetate produced by some plants disrupts the citric acid cycle in herbivores—targeting fundamental cellular metabolism.
Allelopathy—plants producing chemicals to suppress competitors—can result in larger, more herbivore-resistant individuals.
Holly leaves are very smooth and slippery, making it physically difficult for herbivores to eat them—a mechanical defense.
Some plants produce gummosis (sticky sap) that can physically trap and kill small herbivorous insects.
Coconut palms protect their seeds with multiple layers of armor that require efficient tools to break through to the contents.
Autumn leaf color may serve as an honest warning signal of defensive commitment to insect pests that migrate to trees in autumn.
Leaf shedding (abscission) may be a response that provides protection against leaf miners and gall-forming insects.
The optimal defense hypothesis predicts plants invest more in defense when benefits outweigh costs, especially under high herbivore pressure.
Plants in nutrient-poor conditions use carbon-based defenses like tannins; in carbon-poor (shady) conditions, nitrogen-based toxins predominate.
Seeds of edible fruits often contain cyanogenic glycosides like amygdalin—balancing making fruit attractive while protecting seeds.
Some herbivores sequester plant toxins in their own bodies, turning the plant's defense into their own protection against predators.
Macaranga trees have adapted thin stem walls to create domatia (housing) for protective Crematogaster ants.
The corpse flower (Amorphophallus titanum) can take 7-10 years to bloom for the first time, and its bloom lasts only 24-48 hours.
Bamboo is the fastest-growing plant on Earth, with some species growing up to 91 cm (36 inches) in a single day.
The coco de mer palm produces the largest seed of any plant, weighing up to 18 kg (40 lbs).
Wolffia globosa (Asian watermeal) is the smallest flowering plant, measuring only 0.1-0.2 mm in diameter.
The resurrection plant (Selaginella lepidophylla) can survive extreme desiccation, appearing dead for years before reviving with water.
Welwitschia mirabilis from the Namib Desert can live for over 2,000 years and produces only two leaves throughout its entire life.
The sandbox tree (Hura crepitans) explosively disperses its seeds up to 45 meters (150 feet) at speeds of 70 m/s (160 mph).
Squirting cucumbers (Ecballium elaterium) can launch their seeds up to 6 meters away using hydraulic pressure.
The telegraph plant (Codariocalyx motorius) moves its small lateral leaflets in an elliptical pattern even without stimulation.
Dodder (Cuscuta) is a parasitic plant that has lost the ability to photosynthesize and survives entirely by stealing nutrients from hosts.
Dodder plants can 'smell' their preferred host plants and grow toward them before making contact.
The corpse lily Rafflesia has no stems, leaves, or roots—it exists almost entirely within its host plant except when flowering.
Some species of Euphorbia (spurge) can cause severe skin irritation and temporary blindness if sap contacts eyes.
The strangler fig begins life as an epiphyte high in a tree canopy, then sends roots down that eventually kill the host tree.
Brugmansia (angel's trumpets) are so toxic that even touching the flowers can cause hallucinations through skin absorption.
The gympie-gympie (Dendrocnide moroides) stinging tree can cause pain lasting months to years, with some cases leading to suicide.
The gympie-gympie sting is caused by tiny silica hairs that break off in the skin and continue delivering neurotoxin.
Castor beans contain ricin, one of the most toxic naturally occurring substances—just one milligram can kill an adult.
Aconitum (monkshood/wolfsbane) was historically used as arrow poison and to kill wolves—all parts are extremely toxic.
The death camas (Zigadenus) is so toxic that it killed many pioneers who mistook it for edible wild onions.
Oleander is one of the most poisonous garden plants—ingesting a single leaf can be lethal to a child.
Strychnine from Strychnos nux-vomica causes all muscles to contract simultaneously, leading to a rigid arched-back posture in death.
Belladonna (deadly nightshade) gets its name because Italian women used its extract to dilate their pupils, considered beautiful.
The rosary pea (Abrus precatorius) seed is beautiful but deadly—abrin is even more toxic than ricin.
White snakeroot caused 'milk sickness' that killed Abraham Lincoln's mother—cattle ate the plant and toxin passed through milk.
Hemlock (Conium maculatum) was used to execute Socrates—it causes ascending paralysis, eventually stopping the heart.
Some orchids deceive male bees by mimicking female bee pheromones so closely that males attempt to mate with the flowers.
Hammer orchids (Drakaea) have hinged labellums that swing pollen onto bees attempting to copulate with the flower.
The bucket orchid (Coryanthes) traps bees in a bucket of fluid, forcing them to exit through a narrow channel covered in pollen.
Darwin's orchid (Angraecum sesquipedale) has a 30 cm nectar spur; Darwin predicted a moth with a 30 cm tongue before it was discovered.
Fig trees and fig wasps have co-evolved for over 80 million years—each fig species has its own dedicated wasp pollinator.
Female fig wasps die inside the fig after pollinating it; enzymes break down their bodies, so figs aren't 'full of dead wasps'.
Yucca plants and yucca moths are obligate mutualists—neither can reproduce without the other after millions of years of co-evolution.
Acacia ants live inside swollen thorns and attack any herbivore that touches the tree, receiving food and shelter in return.
Some ant-acacias prevent other plants from growing nearby—the ants kill all seedlings, reducing competition for their host.
Cecropia trees have hollow stems where Azteca ants live; the ants attack herbivores and even prune competing vines.
Leafcutter ants are farmers—they cut leaves not to eat but to grow fungus on, which is their actual food source.
The earliest fossil evidence of leafcutter ant fungus farming dates to 50 million years ago—predating human agriculture by millions of years.
Some ants disperse seeds (myrmecochory); seeds have fatty attachments called elaiosomes that ants eat, then discard the seed.
About 11,000 plant species (~5% of flowering plants) depend on ant seed dispersal, including many spring wildflowers.
Trilliums, violets, and many other woodland flowers have seeds dispersed by ants, with the fatty elaiosome as payment.
Nitrogen-fixing bacteria in legume root nodules convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms plants can use, natural fertilizer production.
Alder, bayberry, and Casuarina trees also host nitrogen-fixing bacteria, not just legumes—they colonize poor soils first.
Legume-rhizobia symbiosis is so specific that most legume species only partner with certain bacterial strains.
Mycorrhizal fungi extend plant root systems by up to 100 times, dramatically increasing water and nutrient absorption.
About 90% of land plants form mycorrhizal associations—it's the norm, not the exception, in plant biology.
Orchid seeds are so tiny they require mycorrhizal fungi to germinate—they lack enough nutrients to sprout alone.
Some orchids remain parasitic on fungi throughout life, never developing chlorophyll (myco-heterotrophy).
The ghost orchid (Epipogium aphyllum) has no leaves or chlorophyll and spends years underground before briefly flowering.
Corpse flower Amorphophallus titanium generates heat during blooming to help spread its carrion scent for pollinators.
Skunk cabbage (Symplocarpus foetidus) produces heat through respiration that can melt snow around its emerging flowers.
The sacred lotus (Nelumbo nucifera) can regulate its flower temperature to around 30-35°C regardless of air temperature.
Lotus leaves are superhydrophobic—water beads up and rolls off, carrying dirt with it (the 'lotus effect').
Sacred lotus seeds can remain viable for over 1,000 years—ancient seeds have been successfully germinated.
Some date palm seeds from the Judean Desert have been germinated after 2,000 years of dormancy.
The oldest viable seed ever germinated was from a Silene stenophylla plant, roughly 32,000 years old, found in Siberian permafrost.
Cryopreserved 32,000-year-old Silene tissue was regenerated using placental tissue, not the seed itself—a botanical 'resurrection'.
Century plants (Agave americana) don't actually take 100 years to bloom—typically 10-30 years—but die after flowering once.
Puya raimondii from the Andes blooms once after up to 100 years, producing up to 10,000 flowers on a single spike up to 10m tall.
Plants can count—the Venus flytrap counts trigger hair touches, and Droseraleaves count touches before responding.
Venus flytraps need 5 trigger hair touches to begin enzyme production—they 'count' to distinguish real prey from debris.
Giant water lilies (Victoria amazonica) can support the weight of a small child—their undersides have reinforced rib structures.
Victoria lily pads can grow up to 3 meters (10 feet) in diameter and inspired the design of the Crystal Palace.
Water lilies heat their flowers at night to attract beetle pollinators, then trap the beetles overnight before releasing them.
Cauliflory (fruiting directly from the trunk) occurs in cacao, jackfruit, and jabuticaba—adaptation for bat and other pollinators.
Jackfruit is the largest tree-borne fruit, reaching up to 55 kg (120 lbs) and 90 cm long.
Durian fruit is banned from many hotels and public transport in Southeast Asia due to its powerful smell.
Durian's smell has been compared to 'rotting onions, turpentine, and gym socks', yet many consider it a delicacy.
Sago palms store starch throughout their lives but must be harvested before flowering, or all the starch is used up.
Traveler's palm (Ravenala madagascariensis) stores rainwater at its leaf bases, supposedly providing water to travelers.
The prayer plant (Maranta) folds its leaves upward at night like hands in prayer, a phenomenon called nyctinasty.
Many legumes close their leaves at night, possibly to reduce heat loss or deter nocturnal herbivores.
The sensitive plant Mimosa pudica 'remembers' repeated non-threatening touches and stops responding—a form of habituation.
Mimosa pudica can distinguish between water droplets and more threatening mechanical disturbance, suggesting some sensory discrimination.
Pitcher plant fluid contains enzymes, but also provides habitat for specialized organisms living in this extreme environment.
Some Nepenthes pitcher plants have evolved into 'toilet bowls'—tree shrews defecate in them in exchange for nectar.
Nepenthes hemsleyana has evolved to provide roosts for bats, which deposit nitrogen-rich guano in return.
Tropical rainforests contain more than half of all known plant species despite covering only 6% of Earth's land surface.
A single hectare of rainforest can contain over 400 tree species—more than all of temperate North America.
Epiphytes (air plants) grow on other plants without being parasitic—they just use hosts for physical support.
Spanish moss is not a moss but a flowering plant in the pineapple family that absorbs water and nutrients from the air.
Air plants (Tillandsia) have trichomes—specialized scales—that absorb water and nutrients directly from humid air.
Some bromeliads form 'tanks' that hold water and create entire ecosystems with frogs, insects, and aquatic plants.
The smallest bromeliad, Tillandsia usneoides, has no roots at all—it hangs from trees and absorbs all nutrients from the air.
Mangroves have evolved salt-excreting glands and can grow in seawater—critical coastal ecosystems for fish nurseries.
Mangrove prop roots create habitat for countless marine species while stabilizing shorelines against erosion and storms.
Seagrasses are the only flowering plants adapted to live completely underwater in marine environments.
A Mediterranean seagrass (Posidonia oceanica) clone may be over 100,000 years old—among the oldest living organisms.
Seagrass meadows can store carbon up to 35 times faster than tropical rainforests—critical 'blue carbon' ecosystems.
The titan arum can reach 3 meters (10 feet) tall and produce a smell detectable from half a mile away.
Some plants have C4 photosynthesis, a more efficient method for hot, dry environments—including corn, sugarcane, and many grasses.
CAM photosynthesis in cacti and succulents opens stomata at night to reduce water loss, storing CO2 for daytime use.
The saguaro cactus can live over 150 years and doesn't grow its first arm until around 75-100 years of age.
A large saguaro can store up to 200 gallons (760 liters) of water after a rain and can go two years without rain.
The largest saguaro on record was 78 feet (24 m) tall before it blew over in a storm in 1986.
Cacti evolved their spines from leaves—modified leaves that reduce water loss and protect against herbivores.
Cactus stems perform photosynthesis instead of leaves, using their green skin to capture sunlight.
Glochids on prickly pear cacti are tiny barbed spines that detach easily and cause painful irritation.
The jumping cholla cactus doesn't actually jump, but its segments detach so easily that people feel 'attacked' when brushed.
Lithops (living stones) are so well camouflaged that they're often stepped on before being noticed in their native habitat.
Lithops have 'windows' on top of their leaves that allow light to reach photosynthetic cells inside the plant body.
Tillandsia (air plants) are the only genus with species adapted to every climate zone from tropical to temperate.
Pineapples take 2-3 years to produce one fruit, and the plant usually dies after fruiting, with pups taking over.
Pineapple is the only commercially important fruit in the bromeliad family.
Pineapples contain bromelain, an enzyme that digests protein—this is why fresh pineapple makes your mouth tingle.
Papaya also contains protein-digesting enzymes (papain), traditionally used as meat tenderizer.
Kiwifruit contains actinidin, another protein-digesting enzyme that can prevent gelatin from setting.
The corpse flower Rafflesia has no chlorophyll—it steals all nutrients from its host vine through specialized structures.
Hydnora africana grows completely underground except for its flower, which smells of feces to attract dung beetles.
Balanophora are parasitic plants that look like mushrooms, with flowers so tiny they need magnification to see properly.
Mistletoe seeds are so sticky that birds wipe their beaks on branches to remove them—planting new mistletoe.
Some species of mistletoe can photosynthesize but still parasitize host trees for water and minerals.
Sandalwood is a hemiparasite—it has green leaves but parasitizes roots of surrounding trees for nutrients.
Indian paintbrush (Castilleja) is partially parasitic on grass roots, stealing some nutrients while still photosynthesizing.
Broomrape (Orobanche) is a complete parasite that devastates crops—it has no chlorophyll and steals everything from hosts.
Striga (witchweed) is among the world's most damaging parasitic plants, attacking cereal crops and affecting millions of farmers.
Striga seeds can remain dormant in soil for 20+ years, germinating only when they detect chemicals from host roots.
The corpse flower's underground tuber can weigh over 75 kg (165 lbs), storing nutrients for years between blooms.
Konjac (Amorphophallus konjac) is related to the corpse flower and its corm is used to make shirataki noodles.
Arrow poison frogs get their toxins from the alkaloids in ants and beetles they eat, which the arthropods got from plants.
Curare, the famous arrow poison from South America, comes from plants like Strychnos toxifera and causes paralysis.
Curare led to modern muscle relaxants used in surgery—it paralyzes muscles without affecting consciousness.
Ayahuasca combines two plants: one with DMT (Psychotria viridis) and one with MAO inhibitors (Banisteriopsis caapi).
Indigenous people somehow discovered that combining these two specific plants makes DMT orally active—a biochemical mystery.
Coca leaves have been chewed in South America for thousands of years—coca is the source of cocaine but whole leaves are mild.
Original Coca-Cola contained coca leaf extract until 1903; today a 'decocainized' extract is still used for flavor.
Coffee was supposedly discovered when Ethiopian goatherds noticed their goats acting energetic after eating coffee berries.
Tea was supposedly discovered in 2737 BCE when leaves blew into Chinese Emperor Shennong's boiling water.
All true teas (green, black, oolong, white) come from the same plant species, Camellia sinensis—processing differs.
